Feature Talk - Investor Psychology: A Tale of Two Hemispheres - Gayle Buff

Successful investing demands that we be monitored not only by our more emotional hearts but also by our more rational heads - in other words, that we allow ourselves to be regulated not only by the impressionism of the nonlinear right brain but also by the rationality of the linear left brain. Financial savants teach us that the behavior of the market, although seemingly random, nonetheless has underlying order that emerges over time. In other words, the financial market is a chaotic unpredictable system, with predictable cycles of ups and downs. In truth, it is inevitable that the market will repeatedly rise and fall - but no one can predict exactly when these rallies and subsequent corrections will occur, only that they must.
As investors we must be able to tolerate the necessary uncertainty and anxiety that come with attempting to master an unruly system. We must avoid the temptation to give in to our emotions, all the while retaining our faith in both the constancy of the financial market over time and our own ability to discern its underlying order. It is crucial, therefore, for us to be aware of: (1) how we deal with feeling overwhelmed; (2) the way in which we process the continuous stream of information with which we are constantly being bombarded; and, more generally (3) the characteristic defensive posture we assume in the face of uncertainty and anxiety.

Biography
Ms. Buff is founder and president of Buff Capital Management, a Boston-based investment advisory firm. She is currently an adjunct professor of finance at Northeastern University, and teaches the CFA review course for the Boston Security Analysts Society (BSAS).
For the past 10 years, Medical Economics magazine has selected Ms. Buff as one of its "Top 150 Advisors for Doctors"; she has been widely quoted as an expert by a broad range of media sources, including Kiplinger's, ABCNews.com, and the Wall Street Journal. She is also past chair of the Private Wealth Advisory Committee at CFA Institute and was a director and former president of the BSAS.
Ms. Buff also holds an MBA and was a licensed clinical specialist with an MS in psychiatric nursing.
